properties.headline: Flood Warning issued January 11 at 6:26PM EST until January 12 at 11:17AM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
...A Flood Warning continues for portions of the following waterways
in Indiana...

Big Blue River...Big Walnut Creek...Buck Creek...Driftwood River...
Eagle Creek...East Fork White River...Eel River...Fall Creek...
Flatrock River...Mill Creek...Mississinewa River...Sugar Creek...
Wabash River...White Lick Creek...White River...Wildcat Creek...
Youngs Creek...


.With only minor exception, water levels early Saturday evening on
area waterways continued to rise throughout central and southern
Indiana due to copious rainfall between late Thursday through late
Saturday.  Radar precipitation estimates indicate the heaviest
rainfall of up to 3.50 plus inches has fallen in western Indiana,
chiefly south of Interstate 74.

The large majority of the Wabash, White, and East Fork White Rivers
are expected to flood, with some locations reaching moderate flood
stage.  Crests are expected to reach a height that has not been seen
since February 2019.

Rain will come to an end this Saturday evening, with little or no
precipitation otherwise through Tuesday afternoon.

Please be aware of flooded roads and do not attempt to cross
flooded areas if you cannot see the road.  Occupied vehicles have
been reported in flood waters in Jennings and Morgan counties
Saturday afternoon.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Buck Creek at Acton.
* until Sunday morning.
* At 5:00 PM Saturday the stage was 9.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 10.3 feet by this evening then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage late tonight.
* At 9.5 feet...Flooding in progress along Buck Creek in southeast
Marion and northwest Shelby Counties.  Flooding primarily affects
agricultural land and some recreational areas.  Flooding of Shelby
CR 700N one quarter of a mile east of Shelby CR 875W may begin at
this level especially if Sugar Creek at New Palestine is 7 feet or
higher.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
